Oops, I guess Adam Smith beat me to it in 1776 in describing "animal spirits" in "The Wealth of Nations."

Dr. Krugman, with all due respect, I think you are missing an essential and important facet of monetary policy.

Central banks have been able to stabilize asset prices and markets by instilling confidence in addition to regulating money supply, exchange rates and interest rates.

I think it is increasingly clear that the ability of central banks to provide confidence is being tested.

The specter of a number of central banks resorting to negative nominal interest rates to depreciate their respective currencies is undermining confidence.

Only the US economy is strong enough to turn around this unfortunate turn of events.

Only the Fed has the credibility and global importance to begin the process of normalizing short rates - slowly and deliberately.

The US is largely at full employment with price stability, suggesting negative real rates are no longer appropriate.

It is highly likely the Fed balance sheet will be held to maturity, providing enormous accommodation for years.

Unlike most of the countries resorting to negative nominal interest rates, the US economy is not very dependent on exports at all.

The collapse in oil and gas prices helps to offset the tightening in financial conditions, acting as a convenient tax cut.

Normalizing short rates slowly and modestly is crucial as a signal, as it would provide a boost in confidence to consumers.

It would be entirely appropriate given the progress of the domestic economy and it would help the global economy as well.

@Benjamin Stockton:

First, if you read my post, I am advocating *for* fiscal stimulus - which will indeed create much needed real demand. No disagreement.

Second, we absolutely do *not* need a bubble. A bubble, by definition, is unsustainable.

There has been a long-term secular imbalance in the labor market, caused by low wages, combined with increased efficiency. This has been offset over the decades, by a series of bubbles (tech in 90's, internet around millennium, then the housing bubble (biggest of all). During this time, interest rates have been trending ever downward - meaning that sufficient demand was only obtained by ever-increasing borrowing by the have-lesses, made possible by the low interest rates. Without this borrowing, and without these bubbles, unemployment would have been much higher during this whole period. In fact, even at the peaks of these bubbles, wage pressures never got very high. At the troughs - *very* slack demand.

The proper policy responses, would be fiscal spending on infrastructure, combined with a means of allowing those already working to work fewer hours (by raising wages at the low and middle of the scale). This would create openings for the chronically unemployed, eventually leading to full employment, which would lead to higher wages - and an economy with a secular balance of demand, with higher consumption, and work hours spread more evenly.

We need increased steady Demand through higher wages - not unsustainable borrowing.

Sure, raising interest rates anytime soon (whether in Europe, US, Japan, etc) would be folly.

But, it is also folly to talk about QE and negative real rates as being a significant part of any real solution to the present dilemma of a world wide net lack of demand.

It is folly to ignore the lessons of history, where we learned long ago about "pushing on a string". The idea that investors are actually keeping track of central bank "credibility" when deciding whether to fund a business? Really? Businesses do not consider an "infinite" time frame. If they don't expect at *least* 15% return on new ventures, within a few years, they don't bother. Investing in a losing enterprise to avoid losing money with negative rates? NO! They will hoard some asset sooner than they will invest in losing enterprises. Pulling forward consumption? Will not work - those with cash are already consuming all they wish. This is a chronic / secular problem. Pump priming (pulling consumption/ residential investment forward) just starts another bubble - at best.

Talking about QE and negative real interest rates, distracts from the needed fiscal and wage rising policies. It also hurts the credibility of those who are putting their reputations on the line in advocacy of "negative real interest rates" as a viable solution - sufficient to do the job of spurring demand, and generating full employment and rising wages.

"Such an approach would enable students to use those Pell Grants and other aid to pay for living expenses while they are in community college."

Call me a cynical college professor who has been doing this for a long time, but….

Does anybody besides me read that well-meaning sentence and see "new scam!" developing out of it?

Mr. Brooks is absolutely right that addressing the issue of living expenses - transportation, housing, textbooks, childcare, etc. - is critical when it comes to making community college work. But his critique of President Obama's plan fails because the plan does provide exactly the kind of help Mr. Brooks claims that it does not.

In particular, the funding under Obama's plan would be "first dollars in," which means that they would eliminate the cost of community college before other sources of financial aid - such as Pell Grants - would be counted. Such an approach would enable students to use those Pell Grants and other aid to pay for living expenses while they are in community college.

Another benefit of Obama's community college plan is that it should encourage students to enroll in such colleges - from which they can graduate with little to no debt - instead of in the for-profit "schools" that provide their students with tens of thousands per year of debt but little in the way of education or employment opportunities.

Could we do more to help middle class, working class, and poor students afford educational opportunities? Yes, we can and should. But Obama's plan is a good step in that direction and, not surprisingly, goes much further towards helping such students than anything today's GOP has ever proposed.

In addition to my previous post, I'd like to add that the VA wasn't prepared for all of these Iraq and Afghan vets, since there really wasn't supposed to be a "war", just regime change and the oil & everything left in the hands "our" ex-expatriates. Diagnoses of PTSD were routinely changed to vague "anxiety" disorders or "pre-existing conditions" by unspoken military and VA policies, since the Bush Administration wanted to avoid having the soldiers' suffering linked to their political agendas, and to save money.

It takes awhile to undo the damage, and we should be giving them the time they need. And it also requires some courage of the therapist, to listen to, understand and empathize with these experiences in all of their gory details. "Exposure therapies" and "EMDR" are quick fixes for an overtaxed system whose practitioners can maintain a less painful distance from their patients, and are often chosen for the overly optimistic "data" from their founders and research proponents. This is not intended to hold that all VA providers are not dedicated, caring professionals, but they can only use the tools they are allowed. Many vets decry the "VA system" while praising their clinicians.

I apologize that "my VA" produced such a hollow, and further traumatizing experience.

Personally, I’m divided on the topic of whether or not technology causes us more stress. There’s days where technology makes life easier and less stressful and there’s days where I just want to throw my phone out the window.
Technology helps me by keeping all my dates and appoints in one place that I can easily take wherever I go. Many might ask, “Why don’t you just invest in a planner?” To that question I have a very straight forward answer. My phone has an alarm that sounds whenever my appointments near to remind me to get going. If I write my appointments down in a planner, the event could easily pass me by when I forget about it. This is just one example of how my phone helps me on a daily basis.
Unfortunately, like most things in life, technology also has disadvantages that go along with the benefits. There’s times where all I want to do is relax and just lay down and forget about everything. Unfortunately the beeping on my phone is a constant reminder that I cannot do nothing. It constantly reminds me that I could be doing something.
Overall, I probably lean toward the idea that technology makes our life less stressful and helps society more than it hinders it.
